title: How to Remove a Jar Label

steps.title: Fill a sink or bucket with hot water.
steps.content: Fill a sink or bucket with hot water. The water needs to be deep enough to completely submerge your jar. If you remove the label from more than one jar, the water needs to be deep enough to cover the largest jar. The hotter the water, the better it will dissolve the glue under the label. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Add a few squirts of dish soap.
steps.content: Add a few squirts of dish soap. If you can't find any dish soap, you can also use ordinary hand soap. This will help loosen the label and make it easier to remove.

steps.title: Add in a few cups of white vinegar.
steps.content: Add in a few cups of white vinegar. White vinegar is somewhat acidic, which will help dissolve the glue holding the label to the jar. It will make removing the label and residue easier. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Place the jars inside the sink.
steps.content: Place the jars inside the sink. Take the lids off the jars, and lay them down on their sides so that they fill with water and sink to the bottom.

steps.title: Wait several minutes.
steps.content: Wait several minutes. The longer you wait, the more time the vinegar will have to dissolve the glue under the label. About 30 minutes should be plenty for stubborn labels, but you can check your jars after 10 minutes.

steps.title: Take the jar out of the water and peel the label off.
steps.content: Take the jar out of the water and peel the label off. It should slide off easily. If you get any residue, try to scrape it off using a scrubby sponge.

steps.title: Rinse the jar using clean water and pat it dry.
steps.content: Rinse the jar using clean water and pat it dry. Once the label is off, rinse the jar off, and dry it using a clean towel. Your jar is now ready to use!

steps.title: Remove as much of the label as possible first.
steps.content: Remove as much of the label as possible first. If the label is too difficult to peel off, soak the jar in warm, soapy water for 10 minutes, then peel the label off. You will have some residue, but that is fine. [3] X Research source Avoid using nail polish remover or acetone if your jar is made from plastic. They may distort or discolor the jar. Rubbing alcohol may be safely substituted but it may not be very effective.

steps.title: Pour some nail polish remover onto a paper towel, cloth, or scrubby sponge.
steps.content: Pour some nail polish remover onto a paper towel, cloth, or scrubby sponge. [4] X Research source If the residue is only minimal, you can use a paper towel. If there is a lot of residues, stick with a scrubby sponge. Acetone will also work for this method. Rubbing alcohol may work, but it will not be as effective as nail polish remover or acetone; it is best reserved for light residue.

steps.title: Scrub the residue with it using small, circular motions.
steps.content: Scrub the residue with it using small, circular motions. The chemicals in the nail polish remover or acetone will dissolve any glue and make it easier to scrub off. You may have to reapply the nail polish remover or acetone.

steps.title: Wash the jar using warm, soapy water.
steps.content: Wash the jar using warm, soapy water. This is especially necessary if you plan on using your jar for food storage. Once the jar is clean, pat it dry with a clean towel and use it for your project.

steps.title: Peel off as much of the label as you can.
steps.content: Peel off as much of the label as you can. If the label is stuck firmly to the jar, soak the jar in warm, soapy water for a few minutes, then peel the label off. You will likely have lots of paper and/or glue residue left over, which is fine. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Mix equal parts of baking soda and oil.
steps.content: Mix equal parts of baking soda and oil. You can use any cooking oil, such as canola oil, olive oil, or vegetable oil. [6] X Research source Baby oil will also work in a pinch. For a small-sized jar, you will need about 1 tablespoon of each. [7] X Research source Plain olive oil may work for light, glue reside. [8] X Research source You will need the abrasive baking soda if there is paper, however.

steps.title: Rub the paste over the jar.
steps.content: Rub the paste over the jar. Focus on the areas that have the most residue. You can rub it on using your fingers, a paper towel, or even a cloth.

steps.title: Wait 10 to 30 minutes.
steps.content: Wait 10 to 30 minutes. [9] X Research source [10] X Research source During this time, the oil will penetrate any glue residue and dissolve it. It will make it easier to remove later on.

steps.title: Rub the paste off using a scrubby sponge or some steel wool.
steps.content: Rub the paste off using a scrubby sponge or some steel wool. [11] X Research source Rub the paste using small, circular motions. This will allow the baking soda to scrub off any glue or paper residue.

steps.title: Wash the jar using soap and water, then pat it dry with a towel.
steps.content: Wash the jar using soap and water, then pat it dry with a towel. If you see any residue, you can wipe it off using a paper towel and a few drops of oil.

steps.title: Turn the hairdryer to high heat.
steps.content: Turn the hairdryer to high heat. Keep in mind that some people have had mixed results with this method. It only works if your hairdryer can get very hot and if the label is not that stubborn to remove. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Hold the hairdryer over the label for 45 seconds.
steps.content: Hold the hairdryer over the label for 45 seconds. The heat of the hair dryer will make the glue dry out and turn brittle. This will make the label easier to peel off.

steps.title: Try to peel off a corner of the label.
steps.content: Try to peel off a corner of the label. If needed, use your fingernail or a razor blade to help peel the label off. If it doesn't peel off easily, heat the label for another 45 seconds, then try it again. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Use olive oil to remove any residue, then wash it using warm, soapy water.
steps.content: Use olive oil to remove any residue, then wash it using warm, soapy water. Put a few drops of olive oil into a paper towel, and gently rub any residue spots away. [14] X Research source Wash the jar using warm, soapy water to get rid of the oil, then pat it dry with a clean towel.

steps.title: Fill a sink with hot water.
steps.content: Fill a sink with hot water. Make sure that the water is deep enough to completely submerge your jar on its side. If you are removing the label from multiple jars, make sure that the water is deep enough to completely submerge the largest jar.

steps.title: Add ½ cup (90 grams) of washing soda to the water.
steps.content: Add ½ cup (90 grams) of washing soda to the water. Swish the water with your hand to help it dissolve. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Open the jar, put it into the water, and wait about 30 minutes.
steps.content: Open the jar, put it into the water, and wait about 30 minutes. Let the water get inside the jar so that it weighs it down. [16] X Research source You don't have to wait exactly 30 minutes, but you have to wait long enough for the water to soak the label and dissolve the glue.

steps.title: Take the jar out and peel the label off.
steps.content: Take the jar out and peel the label off. The label should slide off easily. If you see any residue, try to rub it off with your finger first. If it doesn't come off easily, move on to the next step.

steps.title: Use more washing soda to scrub off stubborn spots.
steps.content: Use more washing soda to scrub off stubborn spots. If there is any residue, put some washing soda onto a scrubby sponge, and gently buff the residue.

steps.title: Rinse the jar off using clean water, then pat it dry.
steps.content: Rinse the jar off using clean water, then pat it dry. Your jar will be clean, but there might be some washing soda residue on it. Once you have the label off, rinse the jar using clean water, and then pat it dry with a towel.
